Confined Gradient Descent: Privacy-preserving Optimization for Federated Learning

Yanjun Zhang 0001-5611-3483 The University of QueenslandSt LuciaQueenslandAustralia4067 yanjun.zhang@uq.edu.au ,  Guangdong Bai The University of QueenslandSt LuciaQueenslandAustralia4067 g.bai@uq.edu.au ,  Xue Li The University of QueenslandSt LuciaQueenslandAustralia4067 xueli@itee.uq.edu.au ,  Surya Nepal Data61 CSIRO AustraliaMARSFIELDNew South WalesAustralia2122 Surya.Nepal@data61.csiro.au  and  Ryan K L Ko The University of QueenslandSt LuciaQueenslandAustralia4067 ryan.ko@uq.edu.au
Abstract.

Federated learning enables multiple participants to collaboratively train a model without aggregating the training data. Although the training data are kept within each participant and the local gradients can be securely synthesized, recent studies have shown that such privacy protection is insufficient. The global model parameters that have to be shared for optimization are susceptible to leak information about training data. In this work, we propose Confined Gradient Descent (CGD) that enhances privacy of federated learning by eliminating the sharing of global model parameters. CGD exploits the fact that a gradient descent optimization can start with a set of discrete points and converges to another set at the neighborhood of the global minimum of the objective function. It lets the participants independently train on their local data, and securely share the sum of local gradients to benefit each other. We formally demonstrate CGD ’s privacy enhancement over traditional FL. We prove that less information is exposed in CGD compared to that of traditional FL. CGD also guarantees desired model accuracy. We theoretically establish a convergence rate for CGD. We prove that the loss of the proprietary models learned for each participant against a model learned by aggregated training data is bounded. Extensive experimental results on two real-world datasets demonstrate the performance of CGD is comparable with the centralized learning, with marginal differences on validation loss (mostly within 0.05) and accuracy (mostly within 1%).

1. Introduction

The performance of machine learning largely relies on the availability of large representative datasets. To take advantage of massive data owned by multiple entities, federated learning (FL) is proposed (Konečnỳ et al., 2016b; Yang et al., 2019; Konečnỳ et al., 2016a). It enables participants to jointly train a global model without the necessity of sharing their datasets, demonstrating the potential to address the issues of data privacy and data ownership. It has been incorporated by popular machine learning tools such as TensorFlow (Abadi et al., 2016a) and PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2019), and increasingly spread over various industries.

The privacy preservation of FL stems from its parallelization of the gradient descent optimization, which in essence is an application of stochastic gradient descent (SGD) (or the mini-batch mode) (Konečnỳ et al., 2016b). During the training process, the participants work on the same intermediate global model via a coordinating server (in the centralized FL) (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Abadi et al., 2016b) or a peer-to-peer communication scheme (in the decentralized FL) (Kim et al., 2019; Roy et al., 2019). Each of them obtains the current model parameters, works out a local gradient based on the local data, and disseminates it to update the global model synchronously (Abadi et al., 2016b; Bonawitz et al., 2017) or asynchronously (Hu et al., 2019). This paradigm guarantees data locality, but has been found insufficient for data privacy: although the local gradients can be securely synthesized via a variety of techniques such as differential privacy (DP) (Abadi et al., 2016b; Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; Hu et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2020b), secure multi-party communication (MPC) (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Gascón et al., 2017), and homomorphic encryption (HE) (Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Marc et al., 2019; Sharma and Chen, 2019), the global model parameters that have to be shared are still susceptible to information leakage(cf. Section 5 and (Papernot et al., 2018; Nasr et al., 2019)).

This work further decreases the dependency among participants by eliminating the explicit sharing of the central global model which is the root cause of the information leakage (Fredrikson et al., 2015; Nasr et al., 2019). We propose a new optimization algorithm named Confined Gradient Descent (CGD) that enables each participant to learn a proprietary global model. The CGD participants maintain their global models locally, which are strictly confined within themselves from the beginning of and throughout the whole training process. We refer to these localized global models as confined models, to distinguish them from the global model in traditional FL.

CGD is inspired by an observation on the surface of the typical cost function. The steepness of the first derivative decreases slower when approaching the minimum of the function, due to the small values in the Hessian (i.e., the second derivative) near the optimum (Bottou, 2012). This gives the function, when plotted, a flat valley bottom. As such, a gradient descent algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, when applied on an objective function F𝐹F, could start with a set of discrete points (referred to as a colony and their distance is discussed later). Iteratively descending the colony using the joint gradient of the colony would lead 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} to the neighborhood of F𝐹F’s minimum in the “flat valley bottom”. The points in the colony would also end up with similar losses that are close to the loss of the minimum.

In Figure 1, we illustrate a holistic comparison between the workflow of CGD and that of a gradient decent in traditional FL. In traditional FL, every participant updates the same global model w𝑤w using their local gradients ga,gb,gcsuperscript𝑔𝑎superscript𝑔𝑏superscript𝑔𝑐g^{a},g^{b},g^{c}. In CGD, each participant l𝑙l first independently initializes the starting point of its confined model w1lsuperscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑙w_{1}^{l}. Then, in every training iteration, participants independently compute the local gradient from their current confined model and local data, and then jointly work out the sum of all local gradients and use it to update their confined models (the equation in Figure 1b). By doing this, CGD aims to enhance privacy without sacrificing much model accuracy. For the sake of simplicity, we refer to these two properties as privacy and accuracy.

  • •

    Privacy. CGD should ensure that, throughout the training process, neither local data of a participant nor intermediate results computed on them can be observed by other participants or an aggregator (if any).

  • •

    Accuracy. The prediction made by any confined model should approach the centralized model that were to learn centrally on the gathered data.

The desired privacy enhancement of CGD stems from two aspects, i.e., secrecy of confined models and secrecy of local gradients. For the former, besides always hiding the confined models from each other, each participant independently initializes its w1lsuperscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑙w_{1}^{l} at random. During the training process, any two confined models keep the same distance and never become closer to each other after descending, preventing any participant from predicting models of others. To further boost the unpredictability, each participant could select its own interval range of initial weights to avoid leaking the average distance between the confined models. CGD withstands interval ranges differing by two orders of magnitude. For the latter, CGD incorporates the secure addition operation on the local gradients to calculate their sum. This has been proved to be viable through the additive secret sharing scheme, in which the sum of a set of secret values is collaboratively calculated without revealing any addends (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Bogdanov et al., 2008; Lin and Tzeng, 2005; Tebaa et al., 2012). A previous study (Zhang et al., 2020a) demonstrates it is efficient when applied to achieve decentralization in FL. We prove that the adversary’s observation in CGD is only the sum of local gradients, and it conceals the extra indicative information that traditional FL would leak (cf. Section 5).

We formally prove that CGD ensures convergence. It converges to confined models that are adjacent to the centralized model, and the adjacency is bounded (cf. Section 4). This merit guarantees the accuracy of CGD. We further evaluate the accuracy performance of CGD with two popular benchmark datasets, i.e., MNIST (LeCun and Cortes, 2010) and CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009). Our experiments demonstrate that its accuracy closely approaches that of the centralized learning. When the confined models are initialized with the standard initialization scheme (i.e., the Gaussian distribution of mean 0 and the variance 1), it achieves marginal differences on validation loss  (mostly within 0.05) and accuracy (mostly within 1%) and outperforms state-of-the-art federated learning with differential privacy. Its accuracy performance remains stable even when the interval ranges of initial weights among participants differ by two orders of magnitude.

Contributions

We summarize the main contributions as follows.

  • •

    Confined Gradient Descent For Privacy-enhancing Decentralized Federated Learning. We propose a new optimization algorithm CGD for privacy-preserving decentralized FL. CGD eliminates the explicit sharing of the global model and lets each participant learn a proprietary confined model. CGD retains the merits of traditional FL such as algorithm independence. Therefore, it can easily accommodate any FL schemes regardless of their underlying machine/deep learning algorithms. It also eliminates the necessity of a central coordinating server, such that the optimization can be conducted in a fully decentralized manner.

  • •

    Convergence Analysis. We theoretically establish a convergence rate for CGD under realistic assumptions on the loss function (such as convexity). We prove CGD converges toward the centralized model as the number of iterations increases. The distance between the trained confined models and the centralized model is bounded, and can be tuned by the hyper-parameter setting.

  • •

    Enhanced Privacy Preservation Over Traditional FL. With secrecy of both confined model and local gradients, CGD achieves enhanced privacy preservation over traditional FL. We prove that in CGD, given only the sum of the local gradients, an honest-but-curious white-box adversary, who may control t𝑡t out of m𝑚m participants (where t≤m−2𝑡𝑚2t\leq m-2) including the aggregator for secure addition operation (if any), can learn no information other than their own inputs and the sum of the local gradients from other honest parties, whereas in traditional FL, extra indicative information about local data can be obtained.

  • •

    Functional Evaluations. We implement CGD and conduct experiments on two popular benchmark datasets MNIST and CIFAR-10. The results demonstrate that CGD can closely approach the performance of centralized model on the validation loss and accuracy, with marginal differences on validation loss  (mostly within 0.05) and accuracy (mostly within 1%).

2. Background and Related Works

CGD is an optimization method based on the gradient decent. Therefore, in this section, we review the existing techniques for gradient updates in the traditional FL.

2.1. Stochastic gradient descent

Stochastic gradient descent (SGD) (Robbins and Monro, 1951; Bottou et al., 2018) is an efficient variant of the gradient descent algorithm. It is extensively used for optimizing the objective function in machine learning and deep learning. Given a cost function F𝐹F with the parameter w𝑤w, SGD is defined by

(1) wk+1←wk−αk​1|ξk|​∇F​(wk,ξk),←subscript𝑤𝑘1subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘1subscript𝜉𝑘∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝜉𝑘w_{k+1}\leftarrow w_{k}-\alpha_{k}\frac{1}{|\xi_{k}|}\nabla F(w_{k},\xi_{k}),

where wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} are the parameter at the kt​hsuperscript𝑘𝑡ℎk^{th} iteration, ξk∈ξsubscript𝜉𝑘𝜉\xi_{k}\in\xi is a randomly selected subset of the training samples at the kt​hsuperscript𝑘𝑡ℎk^{th} iteration, and αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} is the learning rate. Equation 1 can generalize to the mini-batch update when 1<|ξk|<|ξ|1subscript𝜉𝑘𝜉1<|\xi_{k}|<|\xi|, and to the batch update when ξk=ξsubscript𝜉𝑘𝜉\xi_{k}=\xi.

In FL, each local participant l∈ℒ𝑙ℒl\in\mathcal{L} holds a subset of the training samples, denoted by ξlsubscript𝜉𝑙\xi_{l}. To run SGD (or the mini-batch update), for each iteration, a random subset ξl,k⊆ξlsubscript𝜉𝑙𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙\xi_{l,k}\subseteq\xi_{l} from a random participant l𝑙l is selected. The participant l𝑙l then computes the gradient with respect to ξl,ksubscript𝜉𝑙𝑘\xi_{l,k}, which can be written as ∇F​(wk,ξl,k)∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙𝑘\nabla F(w_{k},\xi_{l,k}), and shares the gradient with other participants (or a parameter server). All the participants (or the server) can thus take a gradient descent step by

(2) wk+1←wk−αk​1|ξl,k|​∇F​(wk,ξl,k).←subscript𝑤𝑘1subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘1subscript𝜉𝑙𝑘∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙𝑘w_{k+1}\leftarrow w_{k}-\alpha_{k}\frac{1}{|\xi_{l,k}|}\nabla F(w_{k},\xi_{l,k}).

The gradients, if shared in plain text, are subject to information leakage of the local training data. For example, model-inversion attacks (Melis et al., 2019; Fredrikson et al., 2015; Shokri et al., 2017) are able to restore training data from the gradients. In the immediately following sections, we summarize the existing privacy-preserving methods for synthesizing the local gradients, which fall into two broad categories, i.e., secure aggregation and learning with differential privacy.

2.2. Secure aggregation

Secure aggregation typically employs cryptographic mechanisms such as homomorphic encryption (HE) (Chen et al., 2018; Marc et al., 2019; Sharma and Chen, 2019) and/or secure multiparty computation (MPC) (Gascón et al., 2017, 2016; Liu et al., 2017; Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Bonawitz et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2020a) to securely evaluate the gradient ∇F​(wk,ξl,k)∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙𝑘\nabla F(w_{k},\xi_{l,k}) without revealing local data. With ∇F​(wk,ξl,k)∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙𝑘\nabla F(w_{k},\xi_{l,k}), all the participants can thus take a gradient descent step by Equation 2.

Some existing studies fall into this category. For instance, Bonawitz et al.  (Bonawitz et al., 2017) present a secure aggregation protocol that allows a server to compute the sum of user-held data vectors, which can be used to aggregate user-provided model updates for a deep neural network. Mohassel et al. (Mohassel and Zhang, 2017) propose a secure two-party computation (2PC) protocol that supports secure arithmetic operations on shared decimal numbers for calculating the gradient updates using SGD.

Existing FL frameworks employing HE/MPC are mainly based on federated SGD. All the participants in it share and update one and the same global model, and this is subject to membership inference, as revealed by Nasr et al. (Nasr et al., 2019).

2.3. Learning with differential privacy

Another line of studies that approaches to privacy-preserving FL is through differential privacy (DP) mechanism (Zheng et al., 2019; Hagestedt et al., 2019; Abadi et al., 2016b; Song et al., 2013; Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; Dwork et al., 2014; Hu et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2020b; Geyer et al., 2017). The common practice of achieving differential privacy is based on additive noise calibrated to ∇F∇𝐹\nabla F’s sensitivity 𝒮∇F2subscriptsuperscript𝒮2∇𝐹\mathcal{S}^{2}_{\nabla F}. As such, a differentially private learning framework can be achieved by updating parameters with perturbed gradients at each iteration, for example, to update parameters as

(3) wk+1←wk−αk​1|ξl,k|​(∇F​(wk,ξl,k)+𝒩​(0,𝒮∇F2⋅σ2)),←subscript𝑤𝑘1subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘1subscript𝜉𝑙𝑘∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙𝑘𝒩0⋅subscriptsuperscript𝒮2∇𝐹superscript𝜎2w_{k+1}\leftarrow w_{k}-\alpha_{k}\frac{1}{|\xi_{l,k}|}(\nabla F(w_{k},\xi_{l,k})+\mathcal{N}(0,\mathcal{S}^{2}_{\nabla F}\cdot\sigma^{2})),

where 𝒩​(0,𝒮∇F2⋅σ2)𝒩0⋅subscriptsuperscript𝒮2∇𝐹superscript𝜎2\mathcal{N}(0,\mathcal{S}^{2}_{\nabla F}\cdot\sigma^{2}) is the Gaussian distribution (a commonly used noise distribution in differentially private learning frameworks (Dwork et al., 2014)) with mean 00 and standard deviation 𝒮∇F⋅σ⋅subscript𝒮∇𝐹𝜎\mathcal{S}_{\nabla F}\cdot\sigma.

The privacy loss is accumulated with repeated access to the data during training epochs (Abadi et al., 2016b). There is also an inherent tradeoff between privacy and utility of the trained model.

In summary, in all of the above approaches, the global model has to be shared with each participant, leading to the leakage of information. This motivates CGD’s design to eliminate the explicit sharing of the central global model.

3. Confined Gradient Descent

CGD optimizes an objective function in FL with multiple local datasets. It starts with a colony of discrete points, and then uses the combination of their gradients to lead the optimization to another colony of points at the neighborhood of the global optimum. In this section, we formalize this problem and present the workflow of CGD optimization.

3.1. Problem formulation

3.1.1. Optimization objective

Consider a centralized dataset ξ={(xi,yi)}i=1n𝜉subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑛𝑖1\xi=\{(x_{i},y_{i})\}^{n}_{i=1} consisting of n𝑛n training samples. The goal of machine learning is to find a model parameter w𝑤w such that the overall loss, which is measured by the distance between the model prediction h​(w,xi)ℎ𝑤subscript𝑥𝑖h(w,x_{i}) and the label yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} for each (xi,yi)∈ξsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝜉(x_{i},y_{i})\in\xi, is minimized. This is reduced to solving the following problem

(4) arg⁡minw⁡1n​∑i=1nF​(w;ξ)+λ​z​(w),subscript𝑤1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝐹𝑤𝜉𝜆𝑧𝑤\arg\min_{w}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}F(w;\xi)+\lambda z(w),

where F​(w;ξ)𝐹𝑤𝜉F(w;\xi) is the loss function, and z​(w)𝑧𝑤z(w) is the regularizer for w𝑤w. We use w∗subscript𝑤w_{*} to denote the optimal solution of centralized training (i.e., the centralized model).

In the context of FL, we have a system of m𝑚m local participants, each of which holds a private dataset ξl⊆ξsubscript𝜉𝑙𝜉\xi_{l}\subseteq\xi (l∈[1,m])𝑙1𝑚(l\in[1,m]) consisting of a part of the training dataset. The part could be a part of training samples, a part of features that have common entries, or both. Assume the training takes T𝑇T iterations, and let wklsubscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘w^{l}_{k} denote the confined model of participant l𝑙l at the kt​hsuperscript𝑘𝑡ℎk^{th} iteration, where k∈[1,T]𝑘1𝑇k\in[1,T]. Let

(5) gl​(wkl,ξl)=1|ξl|​∇F​(wkl,ξl)superscript𝑔𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙1subscript𝜉𝑙∇𝐹subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙g^{l}(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l})=\frac{1}{|\xi_{l}|}\nabla F(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l})

represent the local gradient with respect to ξlsubscript𝜉𝑙\xi_{l}. We use w∗lsubscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙w^{l}_{*} to denote the final confined model of participant l𝑙l when CGD converges. The objective of CGD is to make w∗lsubscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙w^{l}_{*} located at a neighborhood of the centralized model w∗subscript𝑤w_{*} within a bounded gap.

3.1.2. Attacker setting

We assume an honest-but-curious white-box adversary111A white-box adversary knows the internals of the training algorithms such as the neural network architecture, and can observe the intermediate computations during the training iterations. who may control t𝑡t out of m𝑚m participants (where t≤m−2𝑡𝑚2t\leq m-2), including the aggregator for secure addition operation (if any).

3.2. CGD optimization

Figure 2 illustrates the architecture of CGD (Figure 2c), with a comparison to the centralized training (Figure 2a) and traditional FL (Figure 2b). In the centralized training, the datasets of all participants are gathered for training a single model. In the traditional FL, every participant owns its local training dataset, and updates the same global model wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} via a parameter server using its local model/gradients. The local gradients ∇F​(wk,ξl,k)∇𝐹subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙𝑘\nabla F(w_{k},\xi_{l,k}) can be protected via either secure aggregation (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Zhang et al., 2020a; Marc et al., 2019; Sharma and Chen, 2019; Liu et al., 2017) or differential privacy mechanisms (Abadi et al., 2016b; Song et al., 2013; Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; Dwork et al., 2014; Hu et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2020b). This process can be decentralized by replacing the parameter server with a peer-to-peer communication mechanism (Kim et al., 2019; Roy et al., 2019). In CGD, each participant learns its own confined model (represented by different colors), i.e., each wklsubscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘w^{l}_{k} is different and private. The model updating in CGD synthesizes the information from all training samples by summing up the local gradients, while in federated SGD (Figure 2b), each iteration takes into account only a subset of training samples.

To better position CGD, we summarize the related studies in the literature in Table 1. We use federated SGD to represent the SGD or the mini-batch update in the FL, including both the plain SGD in which the local gradient/model is shared in plaintext, and privacy-preserving SGD via secure aggregation or differential privacy mechanisms. CGD guarantees that each confined model, when CGD converges, is at the neighborhood of the centralized model, retaining the model accuracy (column 5 in Table 1 and proved in Section 4). It also achieves desired privacy preservation compared to the traditional FL (column 6 in Table 1 and detailed in Section 5).

Algorithm 1 outlines CGD optimization for training with the confined model wklsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙w_{k}^{l}. In general, the optimization process consists of the following steps.

  • •

    Initialization. Each participant l𝑙l randomizes its own w1lsuperscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑙w_{1}^{l}. A default setting is to sample based on the Gaussian distribution of mean 0 and the variance 1, which is the standard weight initialization scheme used in most machine learning approaches (Glorot and Bengio, 2010; Krizhevsky et al., 2017; Mishkin and Matas, 2015). To prevent the colluding participants from inferring others’ points by the knowledge of the average distance among the confined models, we introduce a hyper-parameter δlsuperscript𝛿𝑙\delta^{l} to control the interval range of initial weights w1lsuperscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑙w_{1}^{l}, i.e., w1l∼N​[−δl,δl]similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑙𝑁superscript𝛿𝑙superscript𝛿𝑙w_{1}^{l}\sim N[-\delta^{l},\delta^{l}], and allows each participant l𝑙l to independently choose its own δlsuperscript𝛿𝑙\delta^{l}.

  • •

    Step 1. At each iteration k𝑘k, every participant computes the local gradient gl​(wkl,ξl)superscript𝑔𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙g^{l}(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l}) with respect to its current confined model wklsubscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘w^{l}_{k} and own dataset ξlsubscript𝜉𝑙\xi_{l} using Equation 5.

  • •

    Step 2. Securely compute ∑l=1mgl​(wkl,ξl)superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑚superscript𝑔𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙\sum\limits_{l=1}^{m}g^{l}(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l}) which is later used for calculating wk+1lsubscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘1w^{l}_{k+1} (double lines in Figure 2c).

    This step presumes that computational tools exist for securely evaluating the sum of a set of secret values to avoid releasing local gradient gl​(wkl,ξl)superscript𝑔𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙g^{l}(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l}) in plain text. We refer to Section 5 for more detail.

  • •

    Step 3. A scalar stepsize αk>0subscript𝛼𝑘0\alpha_{k}>0 is chosen given an iteration number k∈[1,T]𝑘1𝑇k\in[1,T].

  • •

    Step 4. Every participant takes a descent step on its own wklsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙w_{k}^{l} with αk​∑l=1mgl​(wkl,ξl)subscript𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑚superscript𝑔𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙\alpha_{k}\sum\limits_{l=1}^{m}g^{l}(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l}), i.e., wk+1l←wkl−αk​∑l=1mgl​(wkl,ξl)←superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘1𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙subscript𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑚superscript𝑔𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙w_{k+1}^{l}\leftarrow w_{k}^{l}-\alpha_{k}\sum\limits_{l=1}^{m}g^{l}(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l}).

4. Convergence Analysis

In this section, we conduct a formal convergence analysis on CGD. Convergence analysis has been extensively used in the literature (Hu et al., 2019; Hsieh et al., 2017; Ho et al., 2013) to prove the correctness of optimization algorithms. Through the analysis, we demonstrate the bound of the distance between an arbitrary w∗lsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑙w_{*}^{l} learned by CGD and the centralized model w∗subscript𝑤w_{*}. The analysis is centered around a regret function ℛℛ\mathcal{R}, which is the difference between the CGD’s training loss and the loss of the centralized model, defined as

(6) ℛ=1T​∑k=1T(F​(wkl)−F​(w∗))ℛ1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑇𝐹superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙𝐹subscript𝑤\mathcal{R}=\frac{1}{T}\sum_{k=1}^{T}(F(w_{k}^{l})-F(w_{*}))

4.1. Assumptions

We make the following assumptions on the loss function F𝐹F. They all are common assumptions in convergence analyses of most gradient-based methods, and satisfied in a variety of widely used cost functions (Bottou et al., 2018), such as mean squared error (MSE) and cross entropy.

Assumption 1.

(Lipschitz continuity). The loss function F𝐹F: ℝd→ℝ→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝ\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is continuously differentiable and the gradient function of F𝐹F, namely, ∇F∇𝐹\nabla F: ℝd→ℝd→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d}, is Lipschitz continuous with Lipschitz constant L>0𝐿0L>0,

(7) ‖∇F​(w)−∇F​(w^)‖2≤L​‖w−w^‖2​ for all ​{w,w^}⊂ℝd.subscriptnorm∇𝐹𝑤∇𝐹^𝑤2𝐿subscriptnorm𝑤^𝑤2 for all 𝑤^𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑\|\nabla F(w)-\nabla F(\widehat{w})\|_{2}\leq L\|w-\widehat{w}\|_{2}\text{\quad for all }\{w,\widehat{w}\}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Intuitively, this assumption ensures that the gradient of F𝐹F does not change arbitrarily in the course of descending, such that the gradient can be a proper indicator towards the optimum (Bottou et al., 2018).

Assumption 2.

(Strong convexity). The loss function F𝐹F: ℝd→ℝ→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝ\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is strongly convex such that

(8) F​(w^)≥F​(w)+∇F​(w)T​(w^−w)​ for all ​{w,w^}⊂ℝd.𝐹^𝑤𝐹𝑤∇𝐹superscript𝑤𝑇^𝑤𝑤 for all 𝑤^𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑F(\widehat{w})\geq F(w)+\nabla F(w)^{T}(\widehat{w}-w)\text{\quad for all }\{w,\widehat{w}\}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}.

A useful fact from Assumption 2 for our analysis is

(9) (F​(w)−F​(w∗))≤⟨w−w∗,∇F​(w)⟩​ for all ​w⊂ℝd,𝐹𝑤𝐹subscript𝑤𝑤subscript𝑤∇𝐹𝑤 for all 𝑤superscriptℝ𝑑(F(w)-F(w_{*}))\leq\langle w-w_{*},\nabla F(w)\rangle\text{\quad for all }w\subset\mathbb{R}^{d},

where ⟨⋅,⋅⟩⋅⋅\langle\cdot{,}\cdot\rangle denotes the inner product operation.

In addition, we adopt the same assumption on a bounded solution space used in related studies (Bottou et al., 2018; Hu et al., 2019).

Assumption 3.

(Bounded solution space). The set of {wkl}|k∈[1,T]evaluated-atsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙𝑘1𝑇\{w_{k}^{l}\}|_{k\in[1,T]} is contained in an open set over which F𝐹F is bounded below a scalar Fi​n​fsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑛𝑓F_{inf}, such that

  1. (a)

    there exists a D>0𝐷0D>0, s.t., ‖wkl−w∗‖22≤D2superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙subscript𝑤22superscript𝐷2\|w_{k}^{l}-w_{*}\|_{2}^{2}\leq D^{2} for all k𝑘k, and

  2. (b)

    there exists a G>0𝐺0G>0, s.t., ‖gl​(wkl,ξl)‖22≤G2superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝑔𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙subscript𝜉𝑙22superscript𝐺2\|g^{l}(w_{k}^{l},\xi_{l})\|_{2}^{2}\leq G^{2} for all wkl⊂ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙superscriptℝ𝑑w_{k}^{l}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}.

4.2. Main Theorem

We first present our main theorem below, and leave its proof to Section 4.3. It demonstrates our main result on the converge rate of CGD.

Theorem 1.

Given a cost function satisfying Assumptions 1 - 3, and a learning rate of αk=α(k+μ​T)2subscript𝛼𝑘𝛼superscript𝑘𝜇𝑇2\alpha_{k}=\frac{\alpha}{(k+\mu T)^{2}} (0<μ<10𝜇10<\mu<1), the CGD optimization gives the regret ℛℛ\mathcal{R}

(10) ℛ=O​(ϵ+1μ​T+1+ln⁡|μ​T+1|T)ℛ𝑂italic-ϵ1𝜇𝑇1𝜇𝑇1𝑇\mathcal{R}=O(\epsilon+\frac{1}{\mu T+1}+\frac{\ln|\mu T+1|}{T})

where ϵ=m​‖𝔼j∈m(w1l−w1j)‖italic-ϵ𝑚normsubscript𝔼𝑗𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑗\epsilon=m\|\displaystyle\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{j\in m}(w_{1}^{l}-w_{1}^{j})\|.

The theorem implies the following two remarks.

  • •

    Convergence rate. Both 1μ​T+11𝜇𝑇1\frac{1}{\mu T+1} and ln⁡|μ​T+1|T𝜇𝑇1𝑇\frac{\ln|\mu T+1|}{T} approach 0 as T𝑇T increases, implying that CGD will converge toward the optimum. The convergence rate can be adjusted by the parameter μ𝜇\mu (the effect of μ𝜇\mu is investigated in Section 7.2.2).

  • •

    Bounded optimality gap. When CGD converges, the gap between the confined models and the centralized model is bounded by ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. CGD uses the initialization parameter δlsuperscript𝛿𝑙\delta^{l} to determine the range of w1lsuperscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑙w_{1}^{l} in the way of

    (11) w1l=δl⋅𝑅𝑎𝑛𝑑l​ for all ​l∈(1,m),superscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑙⋅superscript𝛿𝑙superscript𝑅𝑎𝑛𝑑𝑙 for all 𝑙1𝑚w_{1}^{l}=\delta^{l}\cdot\mathit{Rand}^{l}\text{\quad for all }l\in(1,m),

    where 𝑅𝑎𝑛𝑑𝑅𝑎𝑛𝑑\mathit{Rand} is the initialization scheme. A standard 𝑅𝑎𝑛𝑑𝑅𝑎𝑛𝑑\mathit{Rand} used in machine learning is to apply random sampling from the Gaussian distribution of mean 0 and the variance 1, and a standard δ𝛿\delta is 1n1𝑛\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} (where n𝑛n is the sample size) (Glorot and Bengio, 2010). In CGD, each participant determines its own 𝑅𝑎𝑛𝑑lsuperscript𝑅𝑎𝑛𝑑𝑙\mathit{Rand}^{l} and δlsuperscript𝛿𝑙\delta^{l} independently to avoid leaking the average distance among the confined models. Our experiment finds that CGD keeps robust (in terms of validation accuracy) even when the participants select their δlsuperscript𝛿𝑙\delta^{l}s uniformly at random in a range of (10n,0.1n)10𝑛0.1𝑛(\frac{10}{\sqrt{n}},\frac{0.1}{\sqrt{n}}) (cf. Section 7.2.1).

4.3. Proof of Theorem 1

Our proof aims to identify an upper bound of ℛℛ\mathcal{R}. To this end, we consider the trend of the distance from wklsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙w_{k}^{l} to w∗subscript𝑤w_{*}, which would shrink as k𝑘k increases, if there is a bound existing. Since wklsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙w_{k}^{l} is updated using ∑j=1mgj​(wkj,ξj)superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚superscript𝑔𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑗subscript𝜉𝑗\sum\limits_{j=1}^{m}g^{j}(w_{k}^{j},\xi_{j}) (i.e., the descent in CGD), and w∗subscript𝑤w_{*} is obtained by ∇F∇𝐹\nabla F (i.e., the descent in the centralized training), the trend of the distance therefore should be related to the deviation between these two. Exploring this leads to the following lemma which describes this relationship.

In the following, we give the proof of Theorem 1. It calculates a function that is greater than ℛℛ\mathcal{R} based on the convexity of the objective function (Inequation 13). The function can be decomposed into three terms based on Lemma 2 (Equation 14). We then explore the boundedness of each term, and taking these bounds together concludes the proof.

5. Privacy Preservation

The participants in CGD have to share the sum of local gradients, i.e., ∑j=1mgj​(wkj,ξj)superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑚superscript𝑔𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑗𝑘subscript𝜉𝑗\sum\limits_{j=1}^{m}g^{j}(w^{j}_{k},\xi_{j}). A straightforward way is to let each participant release its local gradient gl​(wkl,ξl)superscript𝑔𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙g^{l}(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l}), but it may leak information about ξlsubscript𝜉𝑙\xi_{l} or wklsubscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘w^{l}_{k} (Zhang et al., 2020a). To address this, we incorporate the secure addition operation (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Bogdanov et al., 2008; Lin and Tzeng, 2005; Tebaa et al., 2012) on the local gradients to calculate their sum without releasing each of them. We make use of the additive secret sharing scheme proposed by Bogdanov et al. (Bogdanov et al., 2008), which uses additive sharing over ℤ232subscriptℤsuperscript232\mathbb{Z}_{2^{32}} for securely evaluating addition operations in a multiparty computation environment. It guarantees the secrecy of the addends even though the majority (m−2𝑚2m-2 out of m𝑚m) of participants are compromised. An brief introduction of the additive secret sharing scheme can be found in Appendix A.

In the rest of this section, we explore the privacy preservation of CGD. We demonstrate CGD’s privacy enhancement over traditional FL. We prove that less information is exposed in CGD compared to that of traditional FL.

5.1. Information exposed in CGD

Recall that the involved parties are a set ℒℒ\mathcal{L} of m𝑚m participants denoted with logical identities l∈[1,m]𝑙1𝑚l\in[1,m], and t𝑡t is the adversarial threshold (t≤m−2𝑡𝑚2t\leq m-2) (Section 3.1.2). Let c𝑐c be any subset of ℒℒ\mathcal{L} that includes the compromised and colluding parties.

We demonstrate that, during optimization in CGD, given only the sum of the local gradients which are computed on different confined models, the adversary can learn no information other than their own inputs and the sum of the local gradients from other honest parties, i.e., ∑gkl​(wkl,ξl)∣l∈ℒ∖cevaluated-atsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙𝑙ℒ𝑐\sum g_{k}^{l}(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l})\mid_{l\in\mathcal{L}\setminus c}.

Our analysis is based on the simulation paradigm (Goldreich et al., 2019). It compares what an adversary can do in a real protocol execution to what it can do in an ideal scenario, which is secure by definition. The adversary in the ideal scenario, is called the simulator. An indistinguishability between adversary’s view in real and ideal scenarios guarantees that it can learn nothing more than their own inputs and the information required by the simulator for the simulation. A brief introduction of the simulation paradigm is given in Appendix B.

To facilitate the understanding on our analysis, we first present the used notations. Denote gkℒ′={gkl​(wkl,ξl)}l∈ℒ′superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘superscriptℒ′subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙𝑙superscriptℒ′g_{k}^{\mathcal{L}^{\prime}}=\{g_{k}^{l}(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l})\}_{l\in\mathcal{L}^{\prime}} as the local gradients of any subset of participants ℒ′⊆ℒsuperscriptℒ′ℒ\mathcal{L}^{\prime}\subseteq\mathcal{L} at kt​hsuperscript𝑘𝑡ℎk^{th} iteration. Let V​I​E​Wr​e​a​l​(gkℒ,t,𝒫,c)𝑉𝐼𝐸subscript𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘ℒ𝑡𝒫𝑐VIEW_{real}(g_{k}^{\mathcal{L}},t,\mathcal{P},c) denote their combined views from the execution of a real protocol 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}. Let V​I​E​Wi​d​e​a​l​(gkc,z,t,ℱp,c)𝑉𝐼𝐸subscript𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑐𝑧𝑡subscriptℱ𝑝𝑐VIEW_{ideal}(g_{k}^{c},z,t,\mathcal{F}_{p},c) denote the views of c𝑐c from an ideal execution that securely computes a function ℱpsubscriptℱ𝑝\mathcal{F}_{p}, where z𝑧z is the information required by the simulator 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} in the ideal execution for simulation.

The following theorem shows that when executing CGD with the threshold t𝑡t, the joint view of the participants in c𝑐c can be simulated by their own inputs and the sum of the local gradients from the remaining honest nodes, i.e., ∑gkl∣l∈ℒ∖cevaluated-atsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑙𝑙ℒ𝑐\sum g_{k}^{l}\mid_{l\in\mathcal{L}\setminus c}. Therefore, ∑gkl∣l∈ℒ∖cevaluated-atsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑙𝑙ℒ𝑐\sum g_{k}^{l}\mid_{l\in\mathcal{L}\setminus c} is the only information that the adversary can learn during the execution.

Theorem 1.

When executing CGD with the threshold t𝑡t, there exists a simulator 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} such that for ℒℒ\mathcal{L} and c𝑐c, with c⊆ℒ𝑐ℒc\subseteq\mathcal{L} and |c|≤t\lvert c\lvert\leq t, the output of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} from V​I​E​Wi​d​e​a​l𝑉𝐼𝐸subscript𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙VIEW_{ideal} is perfectly indistinguishable from the output of V​I​E​Wr​e​a​l𝑉𝐼𝐸subscript𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙VIEW_{real}, namely

V​I​E​Wr​e​a​l​(gkℒ,t,𝒫,c)≡V​I​E​Wi​d​e​a​l​(gkc,z,t,ℱp,c)𝑉𝐼𝐸subscript𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘ℒ𝑡𝒫𝑐𝑉𝐼𝐸subscript𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑐𝑧𝑡subscriptℱ𝑝𝑐VIEW_{real}(g_{k}^{\mathcal{L}},t,\mathcal{P},c)\equiv VIEW_{ideal}(g_{k}^{c},z,t,\mathcal{F}_{p},c)

where

z=∑gkl​(wkl,ξl)∣l∈ℒ∖c.𝑧evaluated-atsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑙𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙𝑙ℒ𝑐z=\sum g_{k}^{l}(w^{l}_{k},\xi_{l})\mid_{l\in\mathcal{L}\setminus c}.
Proof.

We define 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} through each training iteration as:

5.2. Information exposed in traditional FL

In this section, we demonstrate information exposed in traditional FL, including plain federated SGD, secure aggregated federated SGD, and differentially private federated SGD.

Secure aggregated federated SGD

In this category of traditional FL (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Zhang et al., 2020a; Marc et al., 2019; Sharma and Chen, 2019; Liu et al., 2017), the local gradients is protected by secure aggregation, and the global model wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} is updated as

where 𝒟⊆ℒ𝒟ℒ\mathcal{D}\subseteq\mathcal{L}. By combing Equation 37 and 35, we have

(38) wk+1←wk−αk​∑lxlT​Δ​(xl​wk,yl)∣l∈𝒟,←subscript𝑤𝑘1subscript𝑤𝑘evaluated-atsubscript𝛼𝑘subscript𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑙𝑇Δsubscript𝑥𝑙subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝑦𝑙𝑙𝒟w_{k+1}\leftarrow w_{k}-\alpha_{k}\sum\limits_{l}x_{l}^{T}\Delta(x_{l}w_{k},y_{l})\mid_{l\in\mathcal{D}},

For example, in linear regression, as x𝒟∖cT​Δ​(x𝒟∖c​wk,y𝒟∖c)=x𝒟∖cT​(x𝒟∖c​wk−y𝒟∖c)superscriptsuperscript𝑥𝒟𝑐𝑇Δsuperscript𝑥𝒟𝑐subscript𝑤𝑘superscript𝑦𝒟𝑐superscriptsuperscript𝑥𝒟𝑐𝑇superscript𝑥𝒟𝑐subscript𝑤𝑘superscript𝑦𝒟𝑐{x^{\mathcal{D}\setminus c}}^{T}\Delta(x^{\mathcal{D}\setminus c}w_{k},y^{\mathcal{D}\setminus c})={x^{\mathcal{D}\setminus c}}^{T}(x^{\mathcal{D}\setminus c}w_{k}-y^{\mathcal{D}\setminus c}), the adversary is able to simulate {x𝒟∖cT​x𝒟∖c,x𝒟∖cT​y𝒟∖c}superscriptsuperscript𝑥𝒟𝑐𝑇superscript𝑥𝒟𝑐superscriptsuperscript𝑥𝒟𝑐𝑇superscript𝑦𝒟𝑐\{{x^{\mathcal{D}\setminus c}}^{T}x^{\mathcal{D}\setminus c},{x^{\mathcal{D}\setminus c}}^{T}y^{\mathcal{D}\setminus c}\}.

Differentially private federated SGD

In most differentially private federated SGD, the local gradients are protected by additive noise mechanism as

(40) wk+1←wk−αk​(gkl​(wk,ξl)+𝒩k),←subscript𝑤𝑘1subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑙𝑘subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝜉𝑙subscript𝒩𝑘w_{k+1}\leftarrow w_{k}-\alpha_{k}(g^{l}_{k}(w_{k},\xi_{l})+\mathcal{N}_{k}),

where 𝒩ksubscript𝒩𝑘\mathcal{N}_{k} denote the noise added at the kt​hsuperscript𝑘𝑡ℎk^{th} iteration. By combing Equation 35, it can be written as

(41) wk+1←wk−αk​(xlT​Δ​(xl​wk,yl)+𝒩k),←subscript𝑤𝑘1subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝛼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑙𝑇Δsubscript𝑥𝑙subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝑦𝑙subscript𝒩𝑘w_{k+1}\leftarrow w_{k}-\alpha_{k}(x_{l}^{T}\Delta(x_{l}w_{k},y_{l})+\mathcal{N}_{k}),

The information exposed among participants is xlT​Δ​(xl​wk,yl)+𝒩ksuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑙𝑇Δsubscript𝑥𝑙subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝑦𝑙subscript𝒩𝑘x_{l}^{T}\Delta(x_{l}w_{k},y_{l})+\mathcal{N}_{k}, and the additive noise 𝒩ksubscript𝒩𝑘\mathcal{N}_{k} prevent one from directly deriving xlT​Δ​(xl​wk,yl)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑙𝑇Δsubscript𝑥𝑙subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝑦𝑙x_{l}^{T}\Delta(x_{l}w_{k},y_{l}) by subtracting wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} and wk+1subscript𝑤𝑘1w_{k+1}. However, with repeated access to the datasets during training epochs, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon (the parameter of privacy loss) accumulates, i.e., privacy degrades, as the effect of added noise being canceled out (Dwork et al., 2014; Abadi et al., 2016b).

5.3. Enhanced privacy over traditional FL

Traditional FL requires all participants to update the same global model during the training process. Every participant thus sees the identical intermediate results, as the same aggregated gradients are shared. This is the root cause of most privacy threats against FL. CGD breaks the mode of single global model, by introducing random variation among the proprietary global models of the participants. The variation hides each global model from other participants, such that the privacy is enhanced in general.

In Table 2, we summarize the privacy enhancement from the perspective of adversary’s observation, i.e, the exposed information to the adversary during the optimization. In traditional FL, the sharing of global model wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k}, even if the local gradients are protected, is still subject to information leakage about the original dataset. By eliminating the sharing of wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} and letting each participant confine its own wklsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙w_{k}^{l}, CGD achieves boosted privacy over traditional privacy-preserving FL. (1) Compared to secure aggregated FL in which indicative information about original datasets can be observed via the sharing of wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} (Theorem 2), the variation among wklsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙w_{k}^{l} in CGD prevents such information from disclosure, and guarantees that only the sum of local gradients is exposed during the optimization (Theorem 1). (2) Compared to differential privacy mechanism in which privacy decays with the increasing training epochs, the variation introduced to each wklsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙w_{k}^{l} hides the local gradients throughout the whole training process, and thus retains privacy regardless of the number of training epochs.

6. Case study: Confined Gradient Descent for a N-layer neural network

CGD can be applicable to any machine learning algorithms that use gradient descent for optimization. In this section, we apply it to a N-layer neural network to demonstrate its usability. We assume that a centralized dataset ξ𝜉\xi is horizontally and vertically partitioned and distributed to m𝑚m participants where m=(mh×mv)𝑚superscript𝑚ℎsuperscript𝑚𝑣m=(m^{h}\times m^{v}), i.e., the number of horizontal partitions multiplied by the number of vertical partitions. The participant l𝑙l owns a private part of the training dataset, denoted by ξl(i,j)subscript𝜉subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗\xi_{l_{(i,j)}} (i∈[1,mh]𝑖1superscript𝑚ℎi\in[1,m^{h}], j∈[1,mv]𝑗1superscript𝑚𝑣j\in[1,m^{v}]), as well as its confined model parameters, denoted by wk(1)​l(i,j)superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘1subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗w_{k}^{(1)l_{(i,j)}},…,wk(N)​l(i,j)superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑁subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗w_{k}^{(N)l_{(i,j)}}. Since each participant owns different confined models and proportion of the dataset, the training prediction y^l(i,j)superscript^𝑦subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗\widehat{y}^{l_{(i,j)}} is also different and kept confined in its owner (shown in Figure 3).

Algorithm 2 presents the detailed algorithm. The participant l𝑙l first randomly initializes its confined model w1(1)​l(i,j)superscriptsubscript𝑤11subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗w_{1}^{(1)l_{(i,j)}},…,w1(N)​l(i,j)superscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑁subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗w_{1}^{(N)l_{(i,j)}} (line 3). The size of the model in the first layer is w(1)​l(i,j)∈ℝdlj×H1superscript𝑤1subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗superscriptℝsubscript𝑑subscript𝑙𝑗subscript𝐻1w^{(1)l_{(i,j)}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{l_{j}}\times H_{1}}, where dljsubscript𝑑subscript𝑙𝑗d_{l_{j}} is the number of features in ξl(i,j)subscript𝜉subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗\xi_{l_{(i,j)}}, and the size of models in the remaining layers is w(r)​l(i,j)∈ℝHr−1×Hrsuperscript𝑤𝑟subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗superscriptℝsubscript𝐻𝑟1subscript𝐻𝑟w^{(r)l_{(i,j)}}\in\mathbb{R}^{H_{r-1}\times H_{r}} (r∈[2,N]𝑟2𝑁r\in[2,N]). It is possible that different participants have different size of w(1)​l(i,j)superscript𝑤1subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗w^{(1)l_{(i,j)}} because the number of features dljsubscript𝑑subscript𝑙𝑗d_{l_{j}} held by each participant may differ, while w(r)​l(i,j)superscript𝑤𝑟subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗w^{(r)l_{(i,j)}} (r∈[2,N]𝑟2𝑁r\in[2,N]) keep the same size in each participant.

Next, we detail the training process in each iteration. In the forward propagation, each participant separately computes the output of each layer ak(1)​l(i,j),…,ak(N)​l(i,j)superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘1subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗…superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑁subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗a_{k}^{(1)l_{(i,j)}},...,a_{k}^{(N)l_{(i,j)}} based on its own confined models (line 5 to 11). Then, they securely evaluate the sum of local gradients from the Nt​hsuperscript𝑁𝑡ℎN^{th} layer to the 2n​dsuperscript2𝑛𝑑2^{nd} layer (line 19 to 21). For the first layer gradient, since the size of w(1)​l(i,j)superscript𝑤1subscript𝑙𝑖𝑗w^{(1)l_{(i,j)}} can be different, the sum of the local gradients gk(1)​ljsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘1subscript𝑙𝑗g_{k}^{(1)l_{j}} is therefore taken among the vertically partitioned participant groups lj={l(1,j),…,l(mh,j)}subscript𝑙𝑗subscript𝑙1𝑗…subscript𝑙superscript𝑚ℎ𝑗l_{j}=\{l_{(1,j)},...,l_{(m^{h},j)}\} (line 22 to 24). 7. Experiments

We implement CGD and evaluate its performance of model accuracy. It is implemented using C++, and we use Eigen library (Guennebaud et al., 2010) to handle matrix operations and ZeroMQ library (Hintjens, 2013) for distributed messaging. Our evaluation focuses on the performance of CGD in terms of validation loss and accuracy, and the influence of the factors (the parameters δ𝛿\delta and μ𝜇\mu) on its performance.

7.1. Performance Evaluation

We evaluate validation loss and accuracy on two popular benchmark datasets: MNIST  (LeCun and Cortes, 2010) and CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009). We compare CGD with the training on aggregated data (referred to as the centralized training), the training on each participant’s local data only (referred to as the local training), and FL with differential privacy (referred to as the DP-FL). CGD is expected to outperform the local training and DP-FL, and approach that of the centralized training. The settings of all trainings are listed below.

  • •

    CGD training. The model is trained using Algorithm 1 on the dataset which is partitioned and distributed to m𝑚m participants, where m=(mh×mv)𝑚superscript𝑚ℎsuperscript𝑚𝑣m=(m^{h}\times m^{v}). We observe that the performance of all confined models are proximal, and thus we report the worst performance in this section.

  • •

    Centralized training (the baseline). We take the performance of centralized training as the baseline. In this setting, the training is on the entire dataset using the batch update.

  • •

    Local training. In this setting, the data and model are distributed to m𝑚m participants in the same way as in CGD. Each participant separately trains their local models from their local data, without sharing the gradients.

  • •

    DP-FL. We take the scheme proposed by Abadi et al. (Abadi et al., 2016b), one of the state-of-the-art differentially private FL schemes, in our experiments. Due to the different setting of network architecture and hyper-parameters, its centralized baseline is slightly different from ours. Therefore, we report the margin between its performance and the performance of its baseline.

7.1.1. MNIST

Our first set of experiments are conducted on the standard MNIST dataset which is a benchmark for handwritten digit recognition. It has 60,0006000060,000 training samples and 10,0001000010,000 test samples, each with 784784784 features representing 28×28282828\times 28 pixels in the image. We use a fully-connect neural network (FNN) with ReLU of 256256256 units and softmax of 10 classes with cross-entropy loss.

We conduct our experiments with CGD’s default settings:

  • •

    μ=0𝜇0\mu=0, leading to a fixed learning rate which is in line with most machine learning algorithms,

  • •

    δ=0.1𝛿0.1\delta=0.1 (cf. Equation 11), and

  • •

    the standard weight initialization scheme based on the Gaussian distribution of mean 0 and variance 1.

Figure 4 summarizes the performance with varying number of participants. In general, CGD stays close to the centralized baseline in both validation loss and accuracy, and as expected, significantly outperforms the local training. In the worst case of m=(1000×112)𝑚1000112m=(1000\times 112) when CGD contains the greatest number of participants, i.e., each participant owns a small proportion consisting of 606060 samples with 777 features, CGD still achieves 0.2090.2090.209 and 93.74%percent93.7493.74\% in validation loss and accuracy respectively, close to 0.0810.0810.081 and 97.54%percent97.5497.54\% of the centralized baseline. In contrast, the performance of local training declines to 2.3482.3482.348 and 11.64%percent11.6411.64\%. Table 3 lists the detailed performance comparison with both centralized and local trainings, and Table 4 lists the comparison with DP-FL. More results are given with varying number of participants in Appendix C (Figure 9 and Table 8).

7.1.2. CIFAR-10

Our second set of experiments are conducted on the CIFAR-10 dataset. It consists of 60000 32×32323232\times 32 colour images in 10 classes (e.g., airplane, bird, and cat), with 6000 images per class. The images are divided into 50000 training images and 10000 test images. We use the ResNet-56 architecture proposed by He et al. (He et al., 2016). It takes as input images of size 32×32323232\times 32, with the per-pixel mean subtracted. Its first layer is 3×3333\times 3 convolutions, and then a stack of 3×183183\times 18 layers is used, with 3×3333\times 3 convolutions of filter sizes {32,16,8}32168\{32,16,8\} respectively, and 181818 layers for each filter size. The numbers of filters are {16,32,64}163264\{16,32,64\} in each stack. The network ends with an average pooling layer, a fully-connected (FC) layer with 102410241024 units, and softmax. Our training data augmentation follows the setting in (He et al., 2016). For each training image, we generate a new distorted image by randomly flipping the image horizontally with probability 0.50.50.5, and adding 4 amounts of padding to all sides before cropping the image to the size of 32×32323232\times 32.

Since our focus is on evaluating the proposed CGD, rather than enhancing the state-of-the-art analysis on CIFAR-10, we utilize the transferability222Transfer learning allows the analyst to take a model trained on one dataset and transfer it to another without retraining (Shin et al., 2016). of convolutional layers to save the computational cost of computing per-example gradients. We follow the experiment setting of Abadi et al. (Abadi et al., 2016b), which treats the CIFAR-10 as the private dataset and CIFAR-100 as a public dataset. CIFAR-100 has the same image types as CIFAR-10, and it has 100 classes containing 600 images each. We use CIFAR-100 to train a network with the aforementioned architecture, and freeze the parameters of the convolutional layers and retrain only the last FC layer on CIFAR-10.

Training on the entire dataset with batch update reaches the validation accuracy of 75.75%percent75.7575.75\%, which is taken as our centralized training baseline333We note that by making the network deeper or using other advanced techniques, better accuracy can be obtained, with the state-of-the-art being about 99.37% (Kolesnikov et al., 2019).. For the CGD training, each participant feeds the pre-trained convolutional layers with their private data partitions, generates the input features to the FC layer, and randomly initializes the confined model parameters of the FC layer. They then take the input to the FC layer as the private local training data, and train a model using Algorithm 1 with δ=0.01𝛿0.01\delta=0.01 and T=6000𝑇6000T=6000.

Figure 5 and Table 5 summarize our experimental results against centralized training and local training. The results on the validation loss and accuracy are generally in line with that on the MNIST dataset. In the worst case of m=(1000×32)𝑚100032m=(1000\times 32), CGD achieves 0.7240.7240.724 and 74.29%percent74.2974.29\% in validation loss and accuracy respectively, which are relatively near to the centralized baseline (0.6750.6750.675 and 75.72%percent75.7275.72\%). Table 6 summarize the results against DP-FL. In line with the results on MNIST, the accuracy difference to the centralized baseline in CGD is smaller than that in DP-FL.

7.2. Influencing Factors of CGD

In this section, we study the influence of initialization and the parameter μ𝜇\mu on CGD performance. This study is conducted with the MNIST dataset.

7.2.1. Role of the initialization

According to Theorem 1, the gap between CGD solution and the centralized model is bounded by ϵ=m​‖𝔼j∈m(w1l−w1j)‖italic-ϵ𝑚normsubscript𝔼𝑗𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑗\epsilon=m\|\displaystyle\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{j\in m}(w_{1}^{l}-w_{1}^{j})\|, in which each w1lsuperscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑙w_{1}^{l} is decided by δ𝛿\delta in Equation 11. Therefore, we investigate how the initialization setting affects CGD’s performance.

To this end, we conduct two experiments in which we mutate parameter δ𝛿\delta while keeping other settings unchanging (i.e., μ=0𝜇0\mu=0 and T=2000𝑇2000T=2000). In the first experiment, we let all participants use the same δ𝛿\delta in {0.1,0.06,0.01,0.001}0.10.060.010.001\{0.1,0.06,0.01,0.001\}, as they are around 160000160000\frac{1}{\sqrt{60000}} (recall that 600006000060000 is the sample size of MNIST). In the other experiment, we let each participant randomly select its own δ𝛿\delta based on the uniform distribution within the range from 0.0010.0010.001 to 0.10.10.1.

The results of our first experiment are shown in Figure 6 and the first five columns in Table 7. In general, as δ𝛿\delta decreases, CGD achieves better performance. This confirms our expectation: decreasing δ𝛿\delta would reduce the value of ‖𝔼j∈mh(w1l−w1j)‖normsubscript𝔼𝑗superscript𝑚ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑗\|\displaystyle\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{j\in m^{h}}(w_{1}^{l}-w_{1}^{j})\|, such that the confined models are closer to the centralized optimum. We have not observed significant difference from δ=0.1𝛿0.1\delta=0.1, 0.060.060.06 and 0.010.010.01. In the case of m=(1000×112)𝑚1000112m=(1000\times 112), the validation accuracy and loss achieve 97.08%percent97.0897.08\% and 0.0960.0960.096 with δ=0.01𝛿0.01\delta=0.01 which outperform 93.74%percent93.7493.74\% and 0.2090.2090.209 in the setting of δ=0.1𝛿0.1\delta=0.1, but both are close to the centralized model whose validation accuracy and loss are 97.61%percent97.6197.61\% and 0.0780.0780.078 respectively. However, δ𝛿\delta cannot be set too small, in order to maintain numerical stability in neural network (Glorot and Bengio, 2010). For example, when we lower δ𝛿\delta to 0.0010.0010.001, the performance starts decreasing.

The results of our second experiment are shown in Figure 7 and the last column in Table 7. When the participants uniformly randomize their δ𝛿\deltas from 0.0010.0010.001 to 0.10.10.1, the performance of CGD is still comparable with the centralized mode. For example, with m=(1000×112)𝑚1000112m=(1000\times 112) participants, CGD achieves 95.82%percent95.8295.82\% and 0.1360.1360.136 in the validation accuracy and loss. This suggests that CGD keeps robust when the δ𝛿\deltas of its participants differ by two orders of magnitude.

7.2.2. Effect of the parameter μ𝜇\mu

According to Theorem 1, the convergence speed of CGD is affected by the parameter μ𝜇\mu. We thus conduct an experiment to investigate this relation. In this experiment, we tune μ𝜇\mu while keeping δ𝛿\delta fixed as 0.10.10.1. For the stepsize (αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k}), we run CGD with a fixed α𝛼\alpha till it (approximately) reaches a preferred point, and then continue our experiment with α1=αsubscript𝛼1𝛼\alpha_{1}=\alpha. This is to keep CGD practical, as each time the stepsize is diminished, more iterations are required. Therefore, the first 600060006000 iterations is run with α=0.01𝛼0.01\alpha=0.01, and then diminish αksubscript𝛼𝑘\alpha_{k} in each of the following 800080008000 iterations.

Figure 8 demonstrates the results with varying μ𝜇\mu for m=(100×49)𝑚10049m=(100\times 49) and m=(1000×112)𝑚1000112m=(1000\times 112). For the case of m=(100×49)𝑚10049m=(100\times 49), μ≥0.01𝜇0.01\mu\geq 0.01 gives a slightly faster speed. CGD reaches the validation accuracy of 95.9%percent95.995.9\% at 11401t​hsuperscript11401𝑡ℎ11401^{th} iteration, 234023402340 iterations (16.7% less) faster than training with μ<0.01𝜇0.01\mu<0.01. For the case of m=1000×112)m=1000\times 112), μ>0.05𝜇0.05\mu>0.05 gives a faster speed. CGD reaches the validation accuracy 95.68%percent95.6895.68\% at 11821t​hsuperscript11821𝑡ℎ11821^{th} iteration, 214021402140 iterations (15.28% less) faster than training with μ≤0.05𝜇0.05\mu\leq 0.05. Even though such slight difference is observed, our experiment suggests that the effect of tuning μ𝜇\mu is relatively limited. The gain of the validation accuracy is only within 0.2%percent0.20.2\% in the cost of around 200020002000 iterations.

8. Conclusion

We have presented CGD, a novel optimization algorithm for learning confined models to enhance privacy for federated learning. Privacy preservation is achieved against an honest-but-curious adversary even though the majority (m−2𝑚2m-2 out of m𝑚m) of participants are corrupted. We formally proved the convergence of CGD optimization. In our experiments, we achieved validation accuracy of 97.01% with (1000×11210001121000\times 112) participants on the MNIST dataset, and 74.4% with (1000×321000321000\times 32) participants on the CIFAR-10 dataset. Both are comparable to the performance of centralized training.

A number of future work directions are of interest. In particular, we see new research opportunities in applying our techniques to asynchronous FL, allowing different participants to be at different iterations of model updates up to a bounded delay. We are also considering other types of deep networks, for example, unsupervised neural networks such as autoencoders.

Appendix A Additive secret sharing scheme

Secret sharing schemes aim to securely distribute secret values amongst a group of participants. CGD employs the secret sharing scheme proposed by (Bogdanov et al., 2008), which uses additive sharing over ℤ232subscriptℤsuperscript232\mathbb{Z}_{2^{32}}. In this scheme, a secret value s​r​t𝑠𝑟𝑡srt is split to s𝑠s shares Es​r​t1,…,Es​r​ts∈ℤ232subscriptsuperscript𝐸1𝑠𝑟𝑡…subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑠𝑠𝑟𝑡subscriptℤsuperscript232E^{1}_{srt},...,E^{s}_{srt}\in\mathbb{Z}_{2^{32}} such that

(42) Es​r​t1+Es​r​t2+…+Es​r​ts≡s​r​tmod232,subscriptsuperscript𝐸1𝑠𝑟𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐸2𝑠𝑟𝑡…subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑠𝑠𝑟𝑡modulo𝑠𝑟𝑡superscript232E^{1}_{srt}+E^{2}_{srt}+...+E^{s}_{srt}\equiv srt\mod 2^{32},

and any s−1𝑠1s-1 elements Es​r​ti1,…,Es​r​tis−1subscriptsuperscript𝐸subscript𝑖1𝑠𝑟𝑡…subscriptsuperscript𝐸subscript𝑖𝑠1𝑠𝑟𝑡E^{i_{1}}_{srt},...,E^{i_{s-1}}_{srt} are uniformly distributed. This prevents any participant who has part of the shares from deriving the value of s​r​t𝑠𝑟𝑡srt, unless all participants join their shares.

In addition, the scheme has a homomorphic property that allows efficient and secure addition on a set of secret values s​r​t1,…,s​r​ts𝑠𝑟subscript𝑡1…𝑠𝑟subscript𝑡𝑠srt_{1},...,srt_{s} held by corresponding participants S1,…,Sssubscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑠S_{1},...,S_{s}. To do this, each participant Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} executes a randomised sharing algorithm S​h​r​(s​r​ti,S)𝑆ℎ𝑟𝑠𝑟subscript𝑡𝑖𝑆Shr(srt_{i},S) to split its secret s​r​ti𝑠𝑟subscript𝑡𝑖srt_{i} into shares Es​r​ti1,…,Es​r​tissubscriptsuperscript𝐸1𝑠𝑟subscript𝑡𝑖…subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑠𝑠𝑟subscript𝑡𝑖E^{1}_{srt_{i}},...,E^{s}_{srt_{i}}, and distributes each Es​r​tijsubscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑗𝑠𝑟subscript𝑡𝑖E^{j}_{srt_{i}} to the participant Sjsubscript𝑆𝑗S_{j}. Then, each Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} locally adds the shares it holds Es​r​t1i,…,Es​r​tsisubscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑖𝑠𝑟subscript𝑡1…subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑖𝑠𝑟subscript𝑡𝑠E^{i}_{srt_{1}},...,E^{i}_{srt_{s}} and produces ∑j=1sEs​r​tjisuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑖𝑠𝑟subscript𝑡𝑗\sum_{j=1}^{s}E^{i}_{srt_{j}} (denoted by Eisuperscript𝐸𝑖E^{i} for brevity). After that, a reconstruction algorithm R​e​c​({(Ei,Si)}Si∈S)𝑅𝑒𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖𝑆Rec(\{(E^{i},S_{i})\}_{S_{i}\in S}), which takes Eisuperscript𝐸𝑖E^{i} from each participant and add them together, can be executed by an aggregator to reconstruct the ∑i=1ss​r​tisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑠𝑠𝑟subscript𝑡𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{s}srt_{i} without revealing any secret addends s​r​ti𝑠𝑟subscript𝑡𝑖srt_{i}.

Appendix B Simulation Paradigm

In simulation paradigm (a.k.a., the real/ideal model) (Goldreich et al., 2019), the security of a protocol is proved by comparing what an adversary can do in a real protocol execution to what it can do in an ideal scenario, which is secure by definition. Formally, a protocol 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} securely computes a functionality ℱpsubscriptℱ𝑝\mathcal{F}_{p}, if for every adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} in the real model, there exists an adversary 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} in the ideal model, such that the view of the adversary from a real execution 𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙subscript𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathit{VIEW_{real}} is indistinguishable from the view of the adversary from an ideal execution 𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙subscript𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathit{VIEW_{ideal}}. The adversary 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} in the ideal model, is called the simulator. An indistinguishability between 𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙subscript𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathit{VIEW_{real}} and 𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙subscript𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathit{VIEW_{ideal}} guarantees that the adversary can learn nothing more than their own inputs and the information required by 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} for the simulation. In other words, the information required by 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} for the simulation is the only information that can leak to adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} from the real execution.

Let c𝑐c denote the set of corrupted parties. The simulator performs the following operations:

  • •

    Generate dummy inputs {ηl}superscript𝜂𝑙\{\eta^{l}\} for each honest party l∉c𝑙𝑐l\notin c and receives the actual inputs {xl}superscript𝑥𝑙\{x^{l}\} of corrupted parties l∈c𝑙𝑐l\in c;

  • •

    Run 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} over {ηl}superscript𝜂𝑙\{\eta^{l}\} (l∉c𝑙𝑐l\notin c ) and {xl}superscript𝑥𝑙\{x^{l}\} (l∈c𝑙𝑐l\in c) and add all messages sent/received by corrupted parties to 𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙subscript𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathit{VIEW_{ideal}};

  • •

    Send the inputs of corrupted parties {xl}superscript𝑥𝑙\{x^{l}\} (l∈c𝑙𝑐l\in c) to the trusted third party;

  • •

    Receive the outputs of corrupted users {yl}superscript𝑦𝑙\{y^{l}\} (l∈c𝑙𝑐l\in c) from the trusted third party and add them to 𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙subscript𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathit{VIEW_{ideal}}.

Meanwhile, a real instance of 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} is executed with actual inputs for all parties, and 𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙subscript𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathit{VIEW_{real}} is created by gathering inputs of corrupted parties, messages sent/received by corrupted parties during the protocol and their final outputs. Once the simulation is finished, the security is proved by showing that 𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙subscript𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑖𝑑𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathit{VIEW_{ideal}} is indistinguishable from 𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙subscript𝑉𝐼𝐸𝑊𝑟𝑒𝑎𝑙\mathit{VIEW_{real}}.
